item.description:
Meg Wolitzer’s new novel The Interestings has just come out. It’s about a group of friends who meet at summer camp  as teenagers then struggle to maintain their relationships despite the changing dynamics of time, talent, money, and intimacy. item.title: Can You Guess These Classic Fictional Characters Just By Their Description?
item.dc:creator: Jeff
item.description:
One of literature’s weaknesses is visualization: we can readily remember who the characters are, what they do, and what they are like, but if I asked you to describe the physical characteristics of some of literature’s greatest characters, how would you do? Well, put yourself to the test. A link to the answer is at [...]

item.title: Our Reading Lives: The Books That Brought Us Together as Writers
item.dc:creator: Rioter in Residence
item.description:
This month, we’re welcoming Rioters in Residence from our 2013 charitable partner organization Girls Write Now. Today’s post is from mentor-mentee pair Julia Salamon and Nishat Anjum. Julie Salamon is an author, critic and journalist who lives in New York City. She’s written eight books in many genres, most recently a biography of the playwright Wendy Wasserstein. For [...]

item.title: Critical Linking: April 13, 2013
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Neace
item.description:
Books aren’t a central part of our culture any more – literature is a bit second tier. There’s plenty of coverage of films, music, TV and video games. It’s rare that you have a water cooler moment regarding a book. The books that do inspire those moments are rarely worth them. Or have we forgotten [...]

item.title: Inbox/Outbox: April 12, 2013
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Joines Schinsky
item.description:
Reading time has been something of a luxury this week, but I’ve been sneaking and grabbing it whenever I can. Ten pages here, fifteen there, three while my French press sets in the morning. It’s not the best way to read, but one could do much worse, and my stolen moments have actually added up [...]

item.title: The 42 Traits of The Perfect Reader
item.dc:creator: Jeff
item.description:
The perfect reader reads in translation, but prefers to read in the original language. The perfect reader reads 50% books by women and 50% books by men. The perfect reader buys exclusively hardbacks from independent bookstores. The perfect reader prefers print. The perfect reader likes plot but doesn’t need it. The perfect reader reads [...]

item.title: SPEAK and Steubenville: Can YA Help?
